This also seems to me like it would be useful.  Just brainstorming here:
 
What if there was a base class called "ConfiguredTestCase," probably
extending TestCase.  The main difference would be that its setup(),
tearDown(), and testXxx() methods would accept a single Map parameter.
Also, every concrete subclass of ConfiguredTestCase, such as FooTest.class,
would be expected to have a corresponding property file, FooTest.properties,
together with it in the CLASSPATH.  This file could define not just one but
an unlimited number of sets of test data:
 
1.name=John Doe
1.height=182
1.birthday=1970-01-01
 
2.name=Jane Doe
2.height=170
2.birthday=1969-12-31
 
And so on.  If n sets of data are given, then creating a single test case
object (say "testCreate" on this class) would automatically create a suite
of n distinct copies of testCreate, which share the same implementation
code, but are assigned a different data set.  They receive this data set as
a Map passed into setup(), tearDown() and testXxx(), with (in this example)
"name," "height," and "birthday" as keys.
 
Of course, these methods would still have to do the appropriate data
conversion.  Perhaps this could even be automated, if there were an
additional section in the properties file:
 
type.name=String
type.height=Integer
type.birthday=java.sql.Date
 
The only types supported would be the standard types (java.lang etc.), plus
any class containing a static "Type fromString(String s)" method.
 
I'm sure these ideas have been thought before, and rejected for perfectly
good reasons.  :-)  What are your opinions on it?
 
Kevin
 

-----Original Message-----
From: Zvi Boshernitzan [mailto:zvi@...]
Sent: Friday, December 22, 2000 12:03 PM
To: junit@egroups.com
Subject: [junit] Parameterized Testing


I'm surprised that despite looking around for a bit, I haven't found any
discussion of how to use Junit to parameterize tests to facilitate
automated testing.  Are there any examples or pointers for people that
would like to use junit for this type of task?  I only see people writing
separate methods for each testcase...  Have any of you used junit in this
way, and might you have any recommendations?  I'm currently using it with
httpunit to test some apis, and would love to hear from you!  (By the way,
Junit is really great - Thanks!)

Thanks again,
Zvi Boshernitzan
